posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
skinny gf edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Enthusiastic eaters who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>>69883528
I wouldn't be surprised if supersetting 6pl8 squat and dead with a bench between em caused the problem desu, that put a lot of very different stresses on your body all in a row in a way that it probably was not used to unless you do that shit a lot.

Bands hit different though, especially if you're not measuring tension and just going with whatever you have. Very easy to overload the hell out of the top 1/3rd of a squat and your body may be making you pay for it now.

Do Zercher, Front, Goblet, or Belt squats hurt at all? If not, I'd full time switch to them for heavy work (relative to the lift) and just treat normal squats like a rehab movement so you don't forget how to do em.

No complaints about this morning's WoD. I realised last night when I was thinking about what I wanted to do that I want a base structure on which I can hang stuff on, with multiple methods of progression and a cardio component. So I'll going to pick time for rounds or rounds for time. Each round is an amount of cardio and a strength movement. The gym layout means I'm limited to dumbbell or kettlebell at the moment.

Tried it out today with 20 minutes max rounds of 20 cal skierg / 5 DB snatch each hand.

Managed 7 rounds, which seems like a decent start. I think initially I'm going to stick with this basic structure and cycle through some different strength movements; DB snatch, DB clean and press, ABCs, front rack carries. I might throw burpees in there too even though I hate them. Once I've cycled through once I can progress on overall time or weight or push for an extra round; today I forgot to put chalk on my hands first for eg and had to wait for it to dry, lost maybe a minute there...

Anyway, nothing ground breaking, but I feel like this is sustainable and changes enough to not become boring and makes me work hard for a decent period of time.

Onto clearing bramble at a nature reserve today and W2D3 of BtM tomorrow. I also should complain here that despite eating the best part of 3700 calories my weight dropped 500g from yesterday to this morning. Robogreg can't keep up, it's had to add over 200 calories to my expenditure in the last 2 weeks and I'm still not gaining weight.

Happy Wednesday. Stay runny plg.

The amount of pain carrying around those extra 30 kg all day caused my knees is insane. Taking off the vest in the evening felt like becoming literally weightless, lmao.

btw, another funny thing that I've realized once I stopped being a fat cunt: I own an electric motorcycle for commuting to work when it's nice weather outside (not because I'm such an environmentalist, but because I hate how noisy normal motorcycles are and because it's cheaper long term) and at one point during my weightloss I noticed that the range of that thing noticably increased after losing that weight. When I was fat, it usually had around 20 % charge left after returning from work in the evening; now it's more like 40 % with 35 kg less, lmao.

>>69877644
He, like most guys were worried about slow weight progression on ohp.
My advice is several things. First of all, work up to higher reps than other compounds, so like a 8-12 rep range before increasing weight. So you can go from 3x12 with 110 lbs to 3x8 with 120 instead of simply failing the weight doing 5s when you’re increasing the weight.
And building a big ohp takes muscle and time, it’s probably better to work on your incline or even flat bench + shoulder isolations and get strong and big shoulders instead of trying to increase weight as fast as possible to get a bodyweight ohp or whatever your goal is.

Idk that seems like an insane increase in volume to me. How many days a week is that? 3/6?
I’d rather just do 2 compounds and one isolation. But alternating starting with press/bench sounds good.
I would rather suggest just adjusting your current routine to something similar to what I’m doing:( only mentioning the upper body lifts here)
Day 1 Flat bench 4x5 1xAmrap, Ohp 4x5 1xAmrap

Day 2
Dumbbell bench, 4x7 last amrap, behind the neck press 4x7 last amrap
Laterals
Day 3
Incline bench 4x5 1x5 amrap
Tricep extensions

Next week lower weight slightly, do +1 rep every set (I.e -5/10 pounds
Next week lower weight slightly do + 1 rep
Last week you’re up to 8/10 and amraps.
Increase weight in week 5 and repeat ( no more than that you can complete at least 5/7 reps on all sets respectively.

2x/week is fine if your doing something like >>69879303 or >>69878921
My OHP day looks like this
>OHP 5/3/1 w/ Joker set and AMRAP for last set
>Weighted Pullups 5/3/1 w/ Joker set and AMRAP for last set
>Kroc Rows 4x10(5th set AMRAP)
>Incline DB Press 4x10(5th set AMRAP)
>Side lateral raises 5x10
>Band Pull Aparts 5x30
and then Bench is like this
>Bench 5/3/1
>Seal Row 5/3/1
>weighted Pullups 4x10 (5th set AMRAP)
>Seated Dumbell OHP 4x10(5th set AMRAP)
>Side lateral raises 5x10
>Band Pull Aparts 5x30
Each week I go up by 5% in weight until I deload at around 7 weeks.
You can do 3 days of OHP if you want but you'd have to cut down on one of those days volume.
Hope this isn't confusing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69877115
Your fat is “stubborn” because you are insulin resistant. Insulin resistance means that you body has to spike insulin higher and keep it elevated longer to do the same job when you eat. Because your insulin is elevated, and insulin tells your body to store energy (not burn it), your fat is harder to access. Fasting lowers insulin resistance, so that’s why people have more success with it.

It’s also easier to put weight back on once you have been fat because you have fat cells built ready to have energy shoved into them. Fat isn’t just stored under your skin, it has to be stored in cells. When you first get fat you get fatter more slowly because your body has to first build fat cells which are metabolically expensive. Once you lose weight you now have empty fat cells ready to hoover up excess food that you eat. Now the fat cells will eventually get broken down once they have been empty for a long time. Or you can accelerate this process by long fasts because your body will begin recycling dead or unused tissues through autophagy.

>>69877429

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As other's have mentioned, it is very difficult for someone to lose weight if they don't actively want to. Forget about any named diets, the only thing that matters is caloric deficit while being reasonably satiated. Drinking wouldn't be a problem if she could forgo snacking and would work it off afterwards.

Your best gameplan is to reduce sweets, garbage meals etc and make more salads and fatty meals. If she likes her snacks, try going every other day without one. Ideally you would reduce this to as low as possible, but you have to take baby steps to form habits. If you can identify what she eats that could be considered "unnecessary" calories, you should first start and reduce or remove them. Take it slow as removing just 1 excess meal a week wothout compensating will be an improvement.

Next it must be said that any sort of extra movement or working out is a huge plus. If she doesn't want to do it on her own, you need to be with her every step of the way. Again, you're main goal is to make it a habit and to get her burning something extra. Going for longer walks 3 times a week, jogging etc. Anything more than sitting is good. The perfect solution would be cardio and some weight training 2x per week each for faster results, but only you can get her to do it, if at all. Maybe try to weasel in how a bit of extra training will make her less tired, but fall asleep faster? Maybe make it a goal together, reward her for following along.

At the end of the day you are trying to manipulate her into becoming a better person. Let's not beat around the bush here. If she joins you in any physical activity you need to praise her. If she follows along with diet restrictions and is losing any sort of weight, tell her how much better she looks. Bartering workout for gift is somewhat bad, but you can work around it and be more giving in one way or the other. Offering to take her someplace nice on the weekend if she joins you on a jog and a workout during workdays might work.

>>69868752
That anon is mislead, if you're morbidly obese you can easily have an 1000 calorie deficit without having hunger pangs or malnutrition. It won't hurt to have some low-impact cardio as well, but diet >>>>>>>>>>>> exercise when it comes to weight loss. In this case you should be able to still eat 1800 calories a day and lose upwards of 2 lbs a week while you're still in the upper 200's. This should last you a while.
>I'm trying to lose weight really quickly without killing myself
Understand the first thing about weight management: It's slow. Even on steroids it's slow. It takes months of hard work to see change reflected in the mirror, and you need to be consistent. Don't think for a second that this will only take a few months, you likely will be dieting for the next year or so.

posts.com: How should I strengthen my wrists? They are my weakest link when I bench, and I was going to start doing wrist curls but I saw someone say they can cause tendonitis so now I'm not sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69869099
So here's the deal with "wrists"; they are a muscle like your jaw; not designed to be worked like biceps or quads and such. Doing exercises specifically for them is a waste of time. Instead you want to assist the muscles that surround your wrists: grip exercises and forearms stuff.
>They are my weakest link when I bench
Your wrists should have next to no bearing on a bench press unless your form is off. The wrists just hold the weight, they don't actually engage in the ROM.

I’m going for a top set of 5. My routine is mad cow with some extra back off sets.
Monday:
Bench: 5x5 starting at 60% 5rm and ending at 100% at 5th set. And then follow with 3 sets at 90% 5rm
Squats and rows: same scheme as bench
Light Deadlift: 3x5 starting at 60% 5rm with last set at 90% 5rm
RDL: 2x10
Weighted sit-ups: 4x15

Wednesday:
OHP: 4x5 starting at 60% 5rm and ending at 100%. Increase by 5 lbs every 2 weeks
Deadlift: same as ohp except 5 lbs every week
Light squats: 1 set at 60%, 1 set at 70%, 2 sets at 80%
Pull-ups: 3 sets until failure
Weighted sit-ups: 4x15
Lateral raises: 3x10

Friday:
bench: same as Monday, except instead of a top set of 5, it’s a top set of 3 at a weight 5 lbs higher than Monday. Next Monday do this new weight for 5. Also on Friday one more set of 8 at the end at 80% 5rm
Squat and row: same as bench
Weighed dips: 3x4-8
Barbell curl: 3x10
Tricep extensions: 3x10


Ex for squat: 110 lbs 140 165 195 220 195 195 195 all for sets of 5 on Monday and
110 140 165 195 all for 5, 225 for 3, 195 195 195 all for 5, then a set of 165 for 8 on Friday. Next Monday do 225 for 5

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69875846
Nice, that's a good start. Reddit's r/bodyweightfitness actually has a pretty well-developed wiki with a bunch of ready-made programs that you can check out for inspiration, and wiki pages for "progressions" for different exercises. Bodyweight-style training depends a lot on progressions for increasing difficulty since you can't usually just throw more weight on you.
Find or create some program that hits for full body 2-3 times a week. Pick progressions that make sense, but don't overthink it; I'd error on the side of easier in the beginning so you can learn proper form. Don't overthink "hitting the full body" either; you're generally fine if a workout does a pushing, pulling and some leg movement. F.ex.:
- Pull-ups, push-ups, squats
- Rows, handstand push-ups / dumbbell presses, kettlebell swings

Pulling and pushing horisontally and vertically, squatting and hinging. These are the six patterns you should hit over the course of a week.

Brodin be with you.

>>69876289
Try different routines. It's natural for DOMS to be tough in the beginning. I assume you pulled some program off the internet. Usually for beginners it's better to take a few sets off whatever prescribed program they're doing, and add the sets back over time as they get used to the program. No harm done with DOMS, though, but it'll affect your motivation and ability to complete workouts and will make you look funny. Kudos to you, though, you are working on yourself, which is more than one can say for NPCs.
About the pain, don't work through it. See a physiotherapist. It might go away as you get used to the program, but I think this might be a nerve-related problem that you've uncovered. You're not fucked, but you should decrease intensity or stop the exercises that cause the pain (find alternatives if possible), and have a professional opinion who can set you up to fix it. I've done this quite a few times over the last decades, it's normal and especially so if you're just starting out, with whatever shitty ergonomics and lifestyle you've been doing in the past.

posts.com:
I've been wondering this in the shower lately, it's about how efficiently the human body utilizes calories.

In the first scenario: I consume 300 calories over maintenance level for 10 days. So that's 3000 excess calories total.
In the second scenario: I consume 3000 calories over maintenance in a single day, and then maintenance for the remaining nine.

Would the net total calories and weight gained be the same in both scenarios? Or would it be less with the single binge day due to the inefficiency of the human body utilizing it's energy sources?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69876624
The net total calories and weight gained would be the same in both scenarios, assuming the same total amount of calories consumed. When you consume more calories than your body needs, the excess calories are stored as fat. This stored fat can then be used as a source of energy when you need it. The body doesn't differentiate between calories consumed in one day versus those consumed over a longer period of time, as long as the total amount of calories consumed is the same.

However, consuming a large amount of calories in one day can have negative health effects, such as digestive discomfort, inflammation, and a higher risk for obesity-related diseases. It's generally recommended to have a balanced diet and not to consume a large amount of calories in one day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69876723
NTA but food kcals are calculated by the Atwater method, which compared bomb calorimetry to ileal absorption, waste, etc. Basically, the kcals on your food labels account for thermic effect and less than perfect absorption of energy.
If you performed bomb calorimetry on what your food labels say is 1000kcal of protein, you would measure more than 1000kcal of total energy, because your food label already assumes some 20% of energy lost during digestion + absorption.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69876883
The reason space out protein to maximise muscle gain is because your body doesn't have any way of storing excess amino acids, other than your muscle - this is why your body breaks down your muscles to gain amino acids when you aren't consuming enough protein.
Excess calories of fat can be stored in your body's fat cells with little or no processing, and your liver can easily turn excess sugar into fat (after glycogen reserves are topped up).

Taken to ridiculous extremes, you eventually just start vomiting or shitting out virtually undigested food, though it depends on what you've eaten and how quickly. Your body has a limited reserve of bile, and dietary fat must bind to bile before your gut can absorb it.
Within a fairly large range though, your body will absorb the vast majority of what you eat.

>>69878500
Then you are 100% doing the wrong routine. That's for strength and honestly it's not a great one.

I suggest giving this a read.
https://www.setforset.com/blogs/news/3-day-workout-split
Push pull legs is proven to be extremely effective (pic related), so is the oldschool 3 day split brosplit.

In the end it's quite simple. Group together 2 muscle groups, hit them hard with 2-3 lifts with a 3x10-12 rep range. (Do 2 warm up sets if its a hard lift). If you don't like a certain lift you can easily replace it with a similar one you do enjoy.

For example
Monday = Chest + Tris
Bench press 3 x 10-12
Incline Bench 3 x 10-12
Dips 3 x 10-12
Tri Extensions 3 x 10-12
Skull Crushers 3 x 10-12


Wed
Back + Bi
Lat Pulldown/Pullups
Rows
Single Arm Cable Row
Cable Curls
Hammer Curls
Incline Bench Curls

Fri
Shoulders + legs
Overhead Press
Arnold Press
Face Pulls
Squat/leg press
Lunges
Leg Extensions

Throw in some abs on a easy day when you have an extra 10 mins.

>at what body fat% is it okay to start cutting after a bulk?
The advice is usually less a number and more "when you're unhappy with the mirror". Your body is just a reflection of yourself, so if you're unhappy with your fat, cut.
>if I do cut, is it really that bad to cut hard?
entirely depends on the definition of "hard". If you mean a starvation deficit of 1000+ calories, then yeah, it's stupid and you'll exhaust yourself and probably lose muscle. If you mean "eat a normal deficit and do cardio 3-4x a week", then no.
>how much muscle can I actually expect to lose if I just cut super hard for a month or so?
If you're only planning to do a month you're not even cutting. The max you could lose is maybe 8 lbs, which is practically nothing in bulking and cutting terms.

>>69883859
For compounds, 10 is a high number of reps. You don't do more than 8 unless following a high-volume program for a specific reason. To make is simple, there's always a balance between reps or weight. If you want to push reps, you need to lower the weight. If you want to push weight, you need to lower the weights. Lean too far either way and you have a recipe for an injury.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69884370
Try to do the most amount of weight you can get through for 3x5 for compounds (squat, deadlift, bench, row) and 3x12 for any accessories/isolations (Shoulder press, curls, pushdowns).

I'd also advise not to do every compound in the same workout. They take a ton of energy compared to isolations. Ideally you follow a routine that allows you to switch off from them day to day (ABxABxx).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nutritionist here with a variety of GI issues, including the hail mary - Ulcerative Colitis, perhaps you've seen me around here

I'll make this crudely short as I want to take a nap very soon
People with autism have a really high chance of having IBS/IBS-like symptoms/food intolerances/high intestinal permiability - or all of the above.

It's the hand that you were dealt, welcome to the club.

The way I would advise you to go about this is to attempt two dietary protocols. Simplest one would be first removing gluten and dairy.

But the two "main" ones would be AIP, and the other one being SCD. They both have their own applications, with AIP's purpose is elimination+identification of triggers mainly, while SCD focuses on the removal of starch.

Why starch? Some evidence suggests that starch can negatively impact pre-existing autism symptoms and the bacteria within starch to act as fuel, especially to those with hightened intestinal permiability, and tendency to fuel said bacteria.

If any sort of tweaking and troubleshooting with those is required, that would depend on changes and symptoms in your digestion - I would futher adjust AIP to be a combination of AIP and low-FODMAP eating, or SCD plus low fodmap eating (IF THE ORIGINAL PROTOCOLS DON'T DO YOU JUSTICE).

AIP+lowFODMAP and SCD+lowFODMAP are both very restrictive, which is why I started you off with the easier options.

I wish you the best anon. Your gut microbiome is obviously impacted by this. I would also considering speaking to a dietician that is mindful of the gut microbiome which has experience with autistic individuals. Nothing to be ashamed of, we all have our issues caused by a variety of poor dietary choices in our childhood/genes.

Ignore the "eat more fiber" anon above, he doesn't even know the difference between soluble and insoluble fiber.

OP, i would also advise you to take this guy's >>69887210 advice regarding fermented foods - but I would start off first with things like 24h fermented homemade yoghurt (which would completely remove all possible lactose), or 24h homemade coconut yoghurt/kefir

We don't, at this present time, know how well you handle insoluble fiber (aka cabbage), so if you want to venture there, I would encourage you to start with the brine from fermented vegetables - perhaps a teaspoon a day and then building up. Others have done the same, so I would look up blogs/videos of other speaking of such protocols.

Regarding your reply anon >>69887210, floating stools could also indicate a simple lipase deficiency; and speaking of which OP, you could also simply find a digestive enzyme trustworthy enough, like Thorne/Enzymedica, which would contain lipase (if you think that might be the issue).

Last piece of advice OP - don't get overwhelmed. Simply start a food journal, and note down protocols implemented and when, as well nutritional supplements ingested and when. When introducting new foods through dietary protocols, introduce one every 2-3 days. Best of luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69880219
It's surprising how much more effort running takes than an elliptical machine. Considering running indoors vs. outdoors: extra exertion, you're dealing with temperature difference, more particulates in the air (pollen, brake dust, dust dust, smog), any or all of which might be activating more allergies than a climate-controlled space.
In your running shoes, and in my cold climate, I'd put on some sort of mask to see if/how much of the issue is alleviated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69879070
I like 3x full body. Like SS/SL but with some accessory work and only squatting every other workout.
Something like:
Work out A
Squats
Bench
Rows
Bicep isolation
Rear delt isolation
Workout B
Deadlifts
overhead press
pull ups
Tricep isolation
front/lateral delt isolation
about 3-5 sets per exercise, either working in the 4-6 rep range or 8-12 rep ranges for compounds depending on your goals and experience. 8-12 reps for isolations. Throw in abs and calves where you can.
Personally I've found I get pretty bad DOMs if I only do legs once a week, but maybe running helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69878431
I recently went to a physio because of a similar problem (jumper's knee) and this is what we did
>1st 45min session: diagnosis, looking for muscular imbalances, flexibility imbalances,...
>2nd 45min session (one day afterwards): creation of a training plan for leg strength, going through all exercises in detail and how to progress
>3rd 45min session (2 months afterwards, just last week): checkup, looking if muscular and flexibility imbalances got better, going through some jumping exercises
I was skeptical too, but the physio did a good job of giving me just the right exercises to make the pain go away. I tried to do my own exercises for months and nothing worked, and then after just one month of doing the suggested exercises the pain was almost gone. The 3 sessions didn't cost the world either, especially because insurance paid half of it.
Physios are now way ahead of doctors in terms of competence in my book.

Some issues:

1. Testosterone can fluctuate a lot. He only has one reading from before the experiment. That low reading could have been an anomaly.
2. Free testosterone readings are inaccurate unless the equilibrium dialysis method is used. This test is more expensive. He didn't mention which method was used to analyze his body fluids.
3. He didn't mention if he had any wet dreams or how often, which could invalidate his results.
4. Some other uncontrolled variable might have been responsible.

40 metres isn't much for chickens. I have 4 hens that I occasionally let free-range in my backyard which is about 250 m and they are making a viable impact on the garden.

Even a few hens will bare earth 40 metres in a few months so they will be dependent on you buying feed and clean straw.

They work to keep them going is free and a lot of fun but my 4 Hens cost me about $100AUD in hay and feed. Every 2-3 months
I'll get about a dozen eggs a week from them.

Cheap eggs if you don't count the costs of the coop (I built mine for about $400) and medicine when they get sick (which they will occasionally)

Also, buy point of lay hens, don't bother with chicks or hatching, you'll just have a bunch of roosters. You still can get protein from them, but only once.(pic related

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think I've had it pretty good most of my life. Dad does a high skilled trade and is coming off the peak of his career making mid six figures, and my mom works as a property manager for a family friend for an additional 50 grand a year, work from home. As such, we have a pretty big property in a metro area, a vacation house overseas, more cars than people in our family, and a lot of disposable income. Additionally, my dad is only on shift for around half the year, so we're frequently together.

What I know is that my parents' wealth is not my wealth, and the difference between us and actual wealth is immense. My mom's boss founded a major consultancy before selling it, and his family is particularly rich. Whereas my family is just cracked-out middle class, theirs is actually wealthy. We have a big house and lots of cars, but they have a portfolio of houses and are also angel investors. We can go on vacation somewhat frequently, but they retired decades ago.

Funnily enough though, the wealthiest people I know tend to be the most troubled. They have all that they need to be fine in life, but everyone around them seeks to leech off their success at their expense. It makes their lives feel suffocating at times as they are constantly afraid of people trying to poach their wealth or get inside "the circle". For us, however, we can live in peace as nobody really cares about our outcome. Being super wealthy is actually more of a chore than anons think.

I guess the point of my ramble was to show that you can be comfortable in life without having to traverse the big wealth chasm that separates the paupers and commoners from the elite. Find the money and lifestyle that makes you happy, not what gives you the biggest statistic to swing around. And, most importantly, always ensure you have a nice physique when you have disposable income.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69884941
>my T levels measured as 327ng/dL
That's fine. It's in the normal healthy range. Free testosterone is more important anyway, as only free testosterone can have biological activity. Also, your androgen receptors and genes are even more important than how much testosterone you have. Testosterone can't exert it's effects in your body until it binds to the androgen receptor and triggers genes. Everyone has different androgen receptor sensitivity, density and different genes. You can't compare your testosterone levels with other people for this reason.
>My doctor says it's in the healthy range and refuses to prescribe me TRT
It is in the healthy range, but he should have checked your free testosterone.
>If doctors will so easily give trans people hormones why is it so hard for a normal person to be prescribed hormones
Because women who want to be men have only about 30 ng/dl testosterone which is not enough to become a man (this is real hypogonadism, not the borderline pseudo hypogonadism that you think you have). Whereas your testosterone levels are over 10 times higher at least and are high enough to convert your body and brain into an adult male.
And it's not easy for them to get testosterone, they have to see psychologists for months and months before being allowed.
>when all I want is to have a low enough dose to put me in the 600ng/dL+ ranges?
Your testosterone might naturally go up to 600 ng/dl but you got your blood test at a time where your testosterone was naturally dipping. Testosterone is constantly fluctuating.
And if you think having 600+ testosterone is going to magically turn you into a chad mentally, you will be disappointed as most TRT mental effects are placebo.

Basically you need to get multiple blood tests with free testosterone/SHBG readings to confirm. Or go to a different doctor that prescribes testosterone easier if you want testosterone so bad. Or just buy it from an UGL. Take power into your own hands.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
if its an impinged nerve, it's likely caused by a herniation. You need to figure out what is causing the impingment, spondylolisthesis can also cause impingement.

If you have a herniation, then extension exercises will help, things like cobra pose. You should also do things like planks and bridges to strengthen the back.

If its something like spondylolisthesis, you'll want to do extension exercises to pain tolerance so you don't lose your flexibility, and also do planks. You can also do more flexion type exercises to strengthen your core. I want to stress that you shouldn't push hard into spinal extension, the only reason I say to do it is to prevent you from adopting a hunched over flexed position because of your back. Going too hard with extension exercises with spondy will make it worse, you aren't building range of motion, you are preserving it.

With these exercises, you should also do sciatic nerve glides, just google them. Look up the McGill big 3 and do those as your warmup for any exercise you do. Do them 2-3 times a day. His book, back mechanic, may be of use to you.

You should also aggressively lose your weight, that's one of the main causes of back pain. I would say in terms of pain relief this may have the most impact. I lost 39% of my bodyweight to help my back pain.

Unfortunately things like back pain and nerve pain are very hard to treat, even with an unlimited amount of medical resources. Even surgery tends to not work and in an alarming amount of cases, cause worse pain. You need to adopt a lifestyle that is focused on back health and that's basically how you live for the rest of your life. One of my physical therapists told me that only people with no back pain can afford to not pay attention to things like their posture or sit in seats that aren't ergonomically designed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69887318
if you don't have back pain, it may be just a herniation. You may also have some kind of traction or compression happening along the nerve somewhere, it's pretty important to figure out where the entrapment of the nerve is.

Dry needling may also help, if its around the L3 and it's just one leg, you can try working on your proximal psoas (part that's connected to your spine) and your quadratus lumborum muscle.

The numbness that you feel is caused by neurapraxia, which is a mild form of nerve damage. Over time with chronic impingement, this can worsen and cause a lot of problems. Thankfully if it's only your anterior thigh that's an issue, it's likely your lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, which is a pretty redundant nerve, it only supplies sensation to your mid antero-lateral thigh, it's not going to be causing any kind of serious functional disability.

You should get at least an x ray to see what the problem is, if the x ray shows nothing, that rules out any kind of bony cause of pain, which means it's likely soft tissue

>>69886661
>Blast and cruise was made up by dealers ....huhhhh yeah man never come offf burn out your receptors hurrr heres some more gear
extremely wrong
turns out, what's really bad for you is your hormones yo-yoing intensely
granted, being on 3+g of harder stuff is probably even worse, but i digress

going off roids will leave you with practically 0 test for some time. worse yet, since estrogen comes from test aromatization, you'll also be low on that too (and decent estogen levels are extremely important for good health)
iirc studies suggest it takes at least 6 months for your hormones to return to normal, during which time you'll be unhealthy, feeling like shit, and hardly repairing and damage done from the cycle

assuming you plan to cycle/blast again fairly soon (lets say within 12 months), its actually healthier to NOT pct and just drop to a TRT-tier test only dose
the hormonal disruption is much less intense and far shorter in duration, plus you don't have to ingest all the PCT drugs
if you try it out on steroidplotter, you'll see that you'll regain normal test (and estrogen) levels within a couple weeks, 4 at most. ofc your HPTA is still shut down, but the rest of your body doesn't know that. it just knows it has the right amount of hormones

ofc if you care about eventually coming off entirely you should be using HCG to keep your balls alive
but aside from that, yea, blast'n'cruise is definitely healthier
assuming ofc the "cruise" part is an actual cruise, not 500mg test lol.

>>69886692
Most tards on this board think that calories are used to create heat and/or mechanical motion, with any excess being stored as fat. On this assumption, your BMR can’t get significantly reduced because if it did you’d be hypothermic and unable to move, which isn’t the case.

What this assumption if ignores is pretty much everything other bodily function, which all require energy: cell repair, immune function, hair growth, brain function, circulation, cell replacement, bone maintenance, lymphatic function, nerve repairs and growth. By down-regulating each system by a little bit, the body can significantly reduce total energy output at the cost of overall health and well-being.

When diet composition or hormonal dysfunction create an insulin imbalance, storing energy as fat will be prioritized over a lot of these functions. Further reducing calories without addressing the underlying issue will eventually result in weight loss, but will continue to disproportionately reduce overall energy use throughout the body

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Inspiratory muscle training, while it won't improve AHI score, it reduces the effect an apnea event has on you and improves QoL of people that do it.

Myofunctional therapy for the tongue, this can reduce severe apnea by up to 50%. This takes an average of 2 years.

You should try an AutoPAP machine if you have a hard time with the CPAP.

You can also buy a neck brace that's made for sleeping to help keep your jaw in the right position. You should also try side sleeping.

You can get a drug induced sleep endoscopy that's offered by a ENT to see where your collapse is coming from. There's a chance he may be able to fix it with surgery, although beware of common surgeries for these issues and fully research the surgery he offers to you.

The other surgical options are Bimax surgery where they break both your jaws and move them forward, or they install a device that will send an electrical signal along the nerve that governs your tongue flexion and it will flex your tongue while you sleep, it's essentially a pacemaker for your tongue.

You should really try hard to get used to the CPAP because it actually is the least invasive treatment for sleep apnea.

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4863204/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7683258/

You can't. That's kind of the point.

Most Arno Brecker sculptures are like a northern European interpretation of the classical ideal. Compared to old Roman or Renaissance statues most Brecker pieces have much narrower hips, they're taller with Nordic spear chucker looking limbs, broader shoulders + some more muscle mass typically. It doesn't matter what of these you prefer, the point is that such depictions of heroes and athletes are somewhat attainable to athletic guys with decent genetics once they get lean and fill out with muscle. Classical interpretations from like Romans and later Brecker are simply better looking to everyone instinctively imo because men like that actually have existed in nature.

But with superheroes everything about them is so beyond human, it's comical to think about trying to look like this. It took guys like Arnold and Lou lifelong dedication and they only somewhat resemble these cartoons, but with all kinds of imbalances and nowhere near as "perfect". If you take a guy with bone structure similar to a comic book superhero, even blasting roids he will still look more like a Brecker or old Roman sculpture than these depictions of batman and superman. A simple program could look like this with your lifting days being Mon-Wed-Fri. Alternate between day 1 and 2. If you want to add things like calves, neck, or abs then it's easy to just tack it on at the end of the day after the rest of the program
>Day 1
Deadlift 4x3-6

Seated Dumbbell OHP 4x8-12

Dumbbell Row 4x8-12

Pushups 3xFailure

GIANTSET x3
Curl of Choice 8-12
Incline Skull Crusher 8-12
Rear Delt Raises 10-15

>Day 2
Squats 4x6-10

Dumbbell Bench Press (slightly higher incline than flat) 4x8-12

Chinups 3xFailure (assisted if needed, then it's 6-10 reps per set)

GIANTSET x3
Cable Lateral Raises 10-15
Curl of Choice 8-12
Cable Pushdown (single arm with the rope recommended) 8-12
Skiers 10-15

posts.sub: Feeling like I don't belong at the gym
posts.com:
I've been lifting for a few months at a private gym and was getting personal training that entire time. I wanted to start doing this by myself at a commercial gym, and today was my first day at a gym on my own. I went first thing in the morning so I could work out before it got too busy. It was so nerve-racking, I felt lost, and I didn't know where the smaller plates were (like 2.5, 5, and 10lb) that I could use for doing squats and press. They only had the bumper plates nearby. Like my brain just gave up on me and I had to ask the employee where they were. He showed me and said it was fine for me to use them after I asked if I could take them for my squats, but he gave me that weird "okayyy..." look after I thanked him.
I felt like such a bumbling idiot. The smaller plates weren't even close to the squat rack and I was nervous of, like, breaking some kind of rule or something by pulling plates from the wrong area. I know it's a silly thing to worry about but I'm just so awkward and nervous of doing the wrong thing, and all this is still new to me. It's intimidating as hell! I was already feeling unsure about doing this alone and I had to force myself to go today, but this really made me feel bad. I don't know if I'm cut out for this. I'm really considering quitting and just sticking to something like running where I don't have to step foot in a gym. I can't image how bad it's going to be during peak hours.

You sound like my springer spaniel dog when he first came to our house. Wait, what were we talking about... oh yeah, so OP you are basically like my dog was who hid under the couch, the timidest most pathetic little creature, but in a few years you could be taking over and not accepting any shit from anyone, unrecognizable from how you were.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69886811
All work is direct work. You are directly locking out your lower triceps on the ohp and pulling your arm back with the upper triceps on chinups while closing the arm with the biceps. Isolations are for when the lifts you are progressing don't hit a certain muscle. For example if he's working on ohps and chinups he would want to do flies for the pecs until he switches it up and progresses the bench press instead of ohp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69886849
The synergist muscles may not be taken close enough to failure to grow though, and typically the bigger muscle will dominate the movement entirely if left unchecked. That's why you have people who get a big bench who end up with huge pecs and small triceps, or a big chinup with big lats and small biceps.
>inb4 just get stronger bro
Yeah obviously if you can do 5pl8 chinups you'll have big biceps but guess what, you can just do curls and get there three times faster.

Also the long head of the tricep doesn't work much on chinups because of the elbow flexion, it works a lot more on straight arm shoulder extension movements (pullovers, front lever pulls, straight arm pulldowns, etc)

Drinking 4 coffees a day, with 6 hours of sleep, while being a skinny twig with low muscle mass, and eating lots of high omega 6 sneed oils, but screen addiction and some recreational drug use.

Low Anxiety:
No coffee, no sneed oils, a bit of healthy exercise each day or time in nature, some socialization time each day.
